ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Physical and Chemical Basis of Bioimaging and Biosensing: MRS, fMRI, PET, etc.
Learned all about the principals of MRI, appreciated cool applications of MRI (especially during the final research proposal). Enjoyed how much math/problem solving was involved!

I learned a great deal about bioimaging and signaling. I think I really honed in on my skills in reading scientific papers and how to digest and learn concepts that are quite advanced. I also gained a lot of experience in writing our final research proposal.

I came in knowing very little, if at all anything, about imaging, and it was frankly a little daunting. With the help of the professors, especially Professor Rothman, I left knowing much more about a wide range of imaging techniques (MRI, fMRI, PET, FRET, etc.) and the math behind it. Especially with the help of the psets, supportive structure of the class, and willingness of the professors to work with students, I learned about the advantages and limitations of relevant imaging techniques in medicine, as well as the concepts that are behind them.
Understanding various principles of bio-imaging, in particular NMR
This course gave the insight about different imaging techniques(MRI,fMRI, PET, ...) including  the chemistry and physics concepts behind them.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The overall course was great. The professors really love what they teach. Professor Rothman is wonderful, always providing problem solving sessions for PSETs and exams. The only improvement would be to have the assignments revised before being given to students, though that's not the end of the world. The problem solving sessions provide a great time to catch any typos and missing information.

Strengths: rothman is the BEST professor - he is always available, providing office hours each week to help with both problem sets and take home assignments. He makes the class worth taking because the actual material can feel very difficult and dry at times. 

Weaknesses: the actual material is very difficult and sometimes lectures were a bit dull since the presentations were filled with lots of words. A lot of concepts flew over my head, but luckily the professors (specifically Dr. Rothman) are so helpful, so you can succeed!

I think the course is organized well and the homework and exams are very fair. The take-home format was great as it allowed me to really engage with the material I didn't always understand the first time around and rewarded me for trying to learn it again rather than punishing me for not grasping important new concepts right away.
A good about of work load, and good material but some aspects felt redundant.

The biggest strengths for this course was the engagement with it and developing the knowledge about imaging. The homework helped us to use the knowledge and better understand the subjects.
The weakness of this course is that it is a requirement even for the students with no interest or related research in imaging.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I'd recommend it if you're interested in concepts related to bioimaging/biosensing and enjoy PSETs with quantitative and sometimes qualitative work.
Yes - purely to have class with Rothman. Also there is a lot of quantum mechanics, physics etc. so be prepared
I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. Although challenging the professors really set you up for success and you learn fascinating things along the way.
The course is required by the department which is why I took the class as a lot of the material didn't apply to my research area
I definitely recommend this course to other biomedical Engineering students specially the ones who are interested in imaging techniques.
